[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

American jazz guitarist and composer (born 1954)

| Pat Metheny |
| --- |
| [![Metheny in 2010](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Pat_metheny_orch2.jpg/440px-Pat_metheny_orch2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pat_metheny_orch2.jpg) Metheny in 2010 |
| Background information |
| Birth name | Patrick Bruce Metheny |
| Born | (1954-08-12) August 12, 1954 (age 69) [Lee's Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee%27s_Summit,_Missouri), Missouri, U.S. |
| Genres | - [Jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz) - [jazz fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz_fusion) - [Latin jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_jazz) - [progressive jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_jazz) |
| Occupation(s) | - Musician - composer - producer - professor |
| Instruments | Guitar |
| Years active | 1974–present |
| Labels | - [ECM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECM_Records) - [Geffen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geffen_Records) - [Warner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros.) - [Nonesuch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonesuch_Records) - Modern Recording |
| |
| Website | [patmetheny.com](http://patmetheny.com) |

Musical artist

**Patrick Bruce Metheny** ([/məˈθiːni/](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English) [_mə-THEE-nee_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key); born August 12, 1954) is an American [jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz) guitarist and composer.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-1)

He was the leader of the [Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group) (1977–2010) and continues to work in various small-combo, duet, and solo settings, as well as other side projects. His style incorporates elements of progressive and contemporary jazz, [latin jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_jazz), and [jazz fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz_fusion).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Yanow2010-2) He has three [gold albums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_albums) and 20 [Grammy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Awards),[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-methany2011-3)[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-4) and is the only person to have won Grammys in 10 categories.

## Biography\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=1)\]

### Early years and education\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=2)\]

Metheny was born in [Lee's Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee%27s_Summit,_Missouri), [Missouri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missouri). His father Dave played trumpet, his mother Lois sang, and his maternal grandfather Delmar was a professional trumpeter.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-6) Metheny's first instrument was the trumpet, on which he was taught by his brother, [Mike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Metheny). Pat's brother, father, and grandfather played trios together at home. His parents were fans of [Glenn Miller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glenn_Miller) and swing music. They took Pat to concerts to hear [Clark Terry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clark_Terry) and [Doc Severinsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doc_Severinsen), but they had little respect for guitar. Pat's interest in guitar increased around 1964 when he saw [the Beatles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beatles) perform on TV. For his 12th birthday, his parents allowed him to buy a guitar, which was a [Gibson ES-140](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibson_ES-140) 3/4.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

Pat Metheny's life changed after hearing the album _[Four & More](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_%26_More)_ by [Miles Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Davis). Soon after, he was captivated by [Wes Montgomery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wes_Montgomery)'s album _[Smokin' at the Half Note](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smokin%27_at_the_Half_Note)_ which was released in 1965. He cites the Beatles, [Miles Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Davis), and Montgomery as having the biggest impact on his music.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

When he was 15, Metheny won a scholarship from _[Down Beat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Down_Beat)_ magazine to a one-week jazz camp where he was mentored by guitarist [Attila Zoller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attila_Zoller), who then invited him to New York City to meet guitarist [Jim Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_(musician)) and bassist [Ron Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_Carter).[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Taylor1999-8)

While playing at a club in Kansas City, Metheny was approached by [Bill Lee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Franklin_Lee_III), a dean at the [University of Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Miami), and offered a scholarship. After less than a week at college, Metheny realized that playing guitar all day during his teens had left him unprepared for classes. He admitted this to Lee, who offered him a job to teach as a professor, as the school had recently introduced electric guitar as a course of study.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

He moved to Boston to teach at the [Berklee College of Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berklee_College_of_Music) with jazz vibraphonist [Gary Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Burton)[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Taylor1999-8) and established a reputation as a prodigy.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Chinen2010-9)

### Debut album\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=3)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Pat_Metheny_KJAZ.jpg/440px-Pat_Metheny_KJAZ.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pat_Metheny_KJAZ.jpg) Metheny at [KJAZ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KEXC) radio, [Alameda, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alameda,_California), December 1980

In 1974, he appeared on an album unofficially titled _[Jaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_(album))_ with pianist [Paul Bley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Bley), bassist [Jaco Pastorius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_Pastorius), and drummer [Bruce Ditmas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Ditmas) on Carol Goss's [Improvising Artists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Improvising_Artists) label—but he was unaware that he was being recorded.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-10) The next year he joined Gary Burton's band with guitarist [Mick Goodrick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Goodrick).

Metheny released his debut album, _[Bright Size Life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bright_Size_Life)_ ( [ECM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECM_Records), 1976), with [Jaco Pastorius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_Pastorius) on bass guitar and [Bob Moses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rakalam_Bob_Moses) on drums. His next album, _[Watercolors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watercolors_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (ECM, 1977), was the first time he recorded with pianist [Lyle Mays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyle_Mays), who became his most frequent collaborator. The album also featured [Danny Gottlieb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danny_Gottlieb), who became the drummer for the first version of the [Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group).[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Ginell-11) With Metheny, Mays, and Gottlieb, the fourth member was bassist [Mark Egan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Egan) when the album _[Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group_(album))_ (ECM, 1978) was released.

## Pat Metheny Group\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=4)\]

Main article: [Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Steve_Rodby_and_Pat_Metheny.jpg/440px-Steve_Rodby_and_Pat_Metheny.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Steve_Rodby_and_Pat_Metheny.jpg) Left to right: [Steve Rodby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Rodby) and Metheny

When _[Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group_(album))_ (ECM, 1978) was released, the group was a quartet comprising, besides Metheny, [Danny Gottlieb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danny_Gottlieb) on drums, [Mark Egan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Egan) on bass, and [Lyle Mays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyle_Mays) on piano, [autoharp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autoharp), and synthesizer. All but Egan had played on Metheny's album _[Watercolors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watercolors_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (ECM, 1977), recorded a year before the first group album.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

The second group album, _[American Garage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Garage)_ (ECM, 1979), reached number 1 on the _Billboard_ jazz chart and crossed over onto the pop charts. From 1982 to 1985, the Pat Metheny Group released _[Offramp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Offramp_(album))_ (ECM, 1982), a live album, _[Travels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travels_(Pat_Metheny_Group_album))_ (ECM, 1983), _[First Circle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Circle_(album))_ (ECM, 1984), and _[The Falcon and the Snowman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Falcon_and_the_Snowman_(album))_ (EMI, 1985), a soundtrack album for the movie of the same name for which they collaborated on the single " [This Is Not America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/This_Is_Not_America)" with [David Bowie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Bowie). The song reached number 14 in the British Top 40 in 1985 and number 32 in the U.S.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-12)

_Offramp_ marked the first appearance of bassist [Steve Rodby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Rodby) (replacing Egan) and a Brazilian guest artist, [Nana Vasconcelos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nana_Vasconcelos), on percussion and wordless vocals. On _First Circle_, Argentinian singer and multi-instrumentalist [Pedro Aznar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Aznar) joined the group; as drummer, [Paul Wertico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Wertico) replaced Gottlieb. Both Rodby and Wertico were members of the [Simon and Bard Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Simon_(musician)) at the time and had played in Simon-Bard in [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago) before joining Metheny.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

_First Circle_ was Metheny's last album with ECM; he had been a key artist for the label but left following disagreements with the label's founder, [Manfred Eicher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manfred_Eicher).[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-13)

_[Still Life (Talking)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Still_Life_(Talking))_ ( [Geffen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geffen_Records), 1987) featured new group members trumpeter [Mark Ledford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Ledford), vocalist David Blamires, and percussionist [Armando Marçal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armando_Mar%C3%A7al). Aznar returned for vocals and guitar on _[Letter from Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter_from_Home_(album))_ (Geffen, 1989).

During this period the [Steppenwolf Theater Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steppenwolf_Theater_Company) of Chicago featured compositions by Metheny and Mays for their production of Lyle Kessler's play _[Orphans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orphans_(Lyle_Kessler_play))_, where it has remained special optional music for all productions of the play around the world since.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-14)

Metheny then again delved into solo and band projects, and four years went by before the release of the next group record, a live album titled _[The Road to You](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Road_to_You)_ (Geffen, 1993), which featured tracks from the two Geffen studio albums among new tunes. The group integrated new instrumentation and technologies into its work, notably Mays' use of synthesizers.

Metheny and Mays themselves refer to the next three Pat Metheny Group releases as a triptych:\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\] _[We Live Here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/We_Live_Here)_ (Geffen, 1995), _[Quartet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartet_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (Geffen, 1996), and _[Imaginary Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imaginary_Day)_ ( [Warner Bros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Records)., 1997). Moving away from the Latin style which had dominated the releases of the previous ten years, these albums included experiments with sequenced synthetic drums on one track, free-form improvisation on acoustic instruments, and symphonic signatures, blues, and sonata schemes.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

With _[Speaking of Now](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaking_of_Now)_ (Warner Bros., 2002), new group members were added: drummer [Antonio Sánchez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_S%C3%A1nchez_(drummer)) from [Mexico City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico_City), trumpeter [Cuong Vu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuong_Vu) from [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam), and bassist, vocalist, guitarist, and percussionist [Richard Bona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Bona) from [Cameroon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cameroon).

_[The Way Up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Way_Up)_ ( [Nonesuch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonesuch_Records), 2005) consists of a single 68-minute-long piece—split into four sections—based on a pair of three-note kernels: the opening B, A♯, F♯ and the derived B, A, F♯. On _The Way Up_, harmonica player [Grégoire Maret](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregoire_Maret) from Switzerland was introduced as a new group member, while Bona contributed as a guest musician.

## Side projects\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=5)\]

Outside the Group, Metheny has shown different sides of his musical personality. He made the album _[Orchestrion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orchestrion_(album))_ ( [Nonesuch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonesuch_Records), 2010) with elaborate, custom mechanical instruments which allowed him to compose and perform as a one-person orchestra. By contrast, his album _[Secret Story](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secret_Story_(album))_ (Geffen, 1992) used orchestral arrangements found more often in movie soundtracks, such as his own _[The Falcon and the Snowman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Falcon_and_the_Snowman_(album))_ (EMI, 1985) and _[A Map of the World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Map_of_the_World_(album))_ (Warner Bros., 1999). His solo acoustic guitar albums include _[New Chautauqua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Chautauqua)_ (ECM, 1979), _[One Quiet Night](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Quiet_Night)_ (Warner Bros., 2003), and _[What's It All About](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/What%27s_It_All_About_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (Nonesuch, 2011). He explored the fringes of the avant-garde on _[Zero Tolerance for Silence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_Tolerance_for_Silence)_ (Geffen, 1994). This, too, was an album of solo guitar, but it was electric guitar. Metheny had ventured into the avant-garde before on _[80/81](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/80/81)_ (ECM, 1980), _[Song X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_X)_ (Geffen, 1986) with [Ornette Coleman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ornette_Coleman), and _The Sign of Four_ with [Derek Bailey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_Bailey_(guitarist)) (Knitting Factory Works, 1997).

In 1997, Metheny recorded with bassist [Marc Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Johnson_(musician)) on Johnson's release _[The Sound of Summer Running](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sound_of_Summer_Running)_ (Verve, 1998). The next year, he recorded a [guitar duet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_%26_Pat_Metheny) with [Jim Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_(musician)) (Telarc, 1999), whose work has strongly influenced Metheny's. He collaborated with Polish jazz and folk singer [Anna Maria Jopek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Maria_Jopek) on _[Upojenie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upojenie)_ (Warner Poland, 2002) and [Bruce Hornsby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Hornsby) on _[Hot House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_House_(Bruce_Hornsby_album))_ (RCA, 2005).

He recorded on albums by his older brother, [Mike Metheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Metheny), a jazz trumpeter, among them _Day In – Night Out_ (1986) and _Close Enough for Love_ (2001).[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-15)[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-16)

The long list of his collaborators includes [Lyle Mays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyle_Mays), [Bill Frisell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Frisell), [Billy Higgins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Higgins), [Brad Mehldau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Mehldau), [Charlie Haden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Haden), [Chick Corea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chick_Corea), [Dave Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Holland), [Dewey Redman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dewey_Redman), [Eberhard Weber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eberhard_Weber), [Herbie Hancock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbie_Hancock), [Jack DeJohnette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_DeJohnette), [Jaco Pastorius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_Pastorius), [Jim Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_(musician)), [John Scofield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Scofield), [Joni Mitchell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joni_Mitchell), [David Bowie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Bowie), [Joshua Redman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_Redman), [Marc Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Johnson_(musician)), [Michael Brecker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Brecker), [Mick Goodrick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Goodrick), [Roy Haynes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Haynes), [Steve Swallow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Swallow), and [Tony Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Williams_(drummer)).[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Forte-17)

## Unity Band\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=6)\]

In 2012, he formed the Unity Band with [Antonio Sánchez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_S%C3%A1nchez_(drummer)) on drums, [Ben Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Williams_(musician)) on bass and [Chris Potter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Potter_(jazz_saxophonist)) on saxophone. This ensemble toured Europe and the U.S. during the latter half of the year. In 2013, as an extension of the Unity Band project, Metheny announced the formation of the Pat Metheny Unity Group, with the addition of the Italian multi-instrumentalist [Giulio Carmassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giulio_Carmassi).

## Influences\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=7)\]

As a young guitarist, Metheny tried to sound like [Wes Montgomery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wes_Montgomery), but when he was 14 or 15, he decided it was disrespectful to imitate him.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Ratliff2005-18) In the liner notes on the 2-disc Montgomery compilation _Impressions: The Verve Jazz Sides_, Metheny is quoted as saying, " _[Smokin' at the Half Note](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smokin%27_at_the_Half_Note)_ is the absolute greatest jazz-guitar album ever made. It is also the record that taught me how to play."

Ornette Coleman's 1968 album _[New York Is Now!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Is_Now!)_ inspired Metheny to find his own direction.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Kitts2002-19) He has recorded Coleman's compositions on a number of albums, starting with a medley of "Round Trip" and "Broadway Blues" on his debut album, _Bright Size Life_ (1976). He worked extensively with Coleman's collaborators, such as [Charlie Haden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Haden), [Dewey Redman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dewey_Redman), and [Billy Higgins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Higgins), and he recorded the album _[Song X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_X)_ (1986) with Coleman and toured with him.

Metheny made three albums on ECM with Brazilian vocalist and percussionist [Naná Vasconcelos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nan%C3%A1_Vasconcelos). He lived in Brazil from the late 1980s to the early 1990s and performed with several local musicians, such as [Milton Nascimento](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milton_Nascimento) and [Toninho Horta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toninho_Horta). He played with [Antônio Carlos Jobim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B4nio_Carlos_Jobim) as a tribute, in a live performance in _[Carnegie Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall) Salutes The Jazz Masters: Verve 50th Anniversary_.

He is also a fan of several pop music artists, especially singer/songwriters including [James Taylor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Taylor) (after whom he named the song "James" on _Offramp_); [Bruce Hornsby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Hornsby), [Cheap Trick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheap_Trick), and [Joni Mitchell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joni_Mitchell), with whom he performed on her _[Shadows and Light](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shadows_and_Light_(Joni_Mitchell_album))_ ( [Asylum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asylum_Records)/ [Elektra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elektra_Records), 1980) live tour. Metheny is also fond of [Buckethead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckethead)'s music. He also worked with, sponsored or helped to make recordings of singer/songwriters from all over the world, such as [Pedro Aznar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Aznar) (Argentina), [Akiko Yano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akiko_Yano) (Japan), [David Bowie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Bowie) (UK), [Silje Nergaard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silje_Nergaard) (Norway), [Noa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achinoam_Nini) (Israel), and [Anna Maria Jopek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Maria_Jopek) (Poland).[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-20)

Two of Metheny's albums, _[The Way Up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Way_Up)_ (2005) and _[Orchestrion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orchestrion_(album))_ (2010), show the influence of American minimalist composer [Steve Reich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Reich) and use similar rhythmic figures structured around pulse. Metheny recorded Reich's composition _[Electric Counterpoint](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_Counterpoint)_ on Reich's album _[Different Trains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Different_Trains)_ (Nonesuch, 1987).

## Guitars\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=8)\]

### Pikasso\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=9)\]

Main article: [Pikasso guitar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pikasso_guitar)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/MethenyPikasso.JPG/440px-MethenyPikasso.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MethenyPikasso.JPG) Metheny with the 42-string Pikasso

Metheny plays a custom-made 42-string [Pikasso I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pikasso_guitar) created by Canadian luthier [Linda Manzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linda_Manzer). He plays it on "Into the Dream" and on the albums _[Quartet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartet_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (1996), _[Imaginary Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imaginary_Day)_ (1997), _[Jim Hall & Pat Metheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_%26_Pat_Metheny)_ (1999), _[Trio → Live](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trio_%E2%86%92_Live)_ (Warner Bros., 2000), and the _Speaking of Now Live_ and _Imaginary Day Live_ DVDs. Metheny has used the guitar in his guest appearances on other artists' albums. He used the Pikasso on _[Metheny/Mehldau Quartet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metheny/Mehldau_Quartet)_ (Nonesuch, 2007), his second collaboration with pianist [Brad Mehldau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Mehldau) and his trio sidemen [Larry Grenadier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Grenadier) and [Jeff Ballard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Ballard_(musician)); the Pikasso is featured on Metheny's composition "The Sound of Water". Manzer has made many acoustic guitars for Metheny, including a mini guitar, an acoustic sitar guitar, and the [baritone guitar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baritone_guitar), which Metheny used for the recording of _[One Quiet Night](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Quiet_Night)_ (2003).

### Guitar synthesizer\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=10)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Pat_Metheny_Venice.jpg/340px-Pat_Metheny_Venice.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pat_Metheny_Venice.jpg) Metheny with the guitar synthesizer

Metheny was one of the first jazz guitarists to use the [Roland GR-300](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roland_GR-300) [guitar synthesizer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guitar_synthesizer). He commented, "you have to stop thinking about it as a guitar, because it no longer is a guitar." He approaches it as if he were a horn player, and he prefers the "high trumpet" sound of the instrument.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-webb-21) One of the patches that he has often used is on Roland's JV-80 "Vintage Synth" expansion card, titled "Pat's GR-300".\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\] In addition to the Roland, he uses a [Synclavier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synclavier) controller.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-webb-21)

### Six-string and twelve-string electric\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=11)\]

Metheny was an early proponent of the [twelve-string guitar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelve-string_guitar) in jazz. During his 1975 tour with the [Gary Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Burton) "Quartet" (five people, including Metheny), he primarily played electric twelve-string guitar against the six-string work of resident guitarist [Mick Goodrick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Goodrick).[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-22)

Prior to Metheny, [Pat Martino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Martino) had used the electric twelve-string guitar on a studio album, _[Desperado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desperado_(Pat_Martino_album))_, and [John McLaughlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McLaughlin_(musician)) had used a double-neck electric guitar with the [Mahavishnu Orchestra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahavishnu_Orchestra). [Ralph Towner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Towner) was perhaps the first[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-23) to use acoustic twelve-string guitar extensively in jazz ("The Moors", from [Weather Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_Report)'s _[I Sing the Body Electric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Sing_the_Body_Electric_(album))_, Columbia, 1972), and [Larry Coryell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Coryell) and [Philip Catherine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Catherine) made extensive use of acoustic twelve string in alternate tunings at the 1975 [Montreux Jazz Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montreux_Jazz_Festival), later releasing some of the material on their 1976 _[Twin House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twin_House_(Larry_Coryell_%26_Philip_Catherine_album))_ album.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

Metheny used a twelve-string guitar on his debut album, _Bright Size Life_ (1976), including alternate tuning on "Sirabhorn", and on later albums ("San Lorenzo", from _Pat Metheny Group_ and _Travels_).\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

### Use of hollow-body electric guitars\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=12)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jazzvitoria_Metheny.jpg/440px-Jazzvitoria_Metheny.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jazzvitoria_Metheny.jpg) Metheny with his Ibanez PM signature model

At the age of 12, Metheny bought a natural finish [Gibson ES-175](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibson_ES-175) that he played throughout his early career, until it was retired in 1995.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-24) After his first tour of Japan in 1978, he began an association with [Ibanez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibanez) guitars, who have since produced a range of PM signature models.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-25)

## Personal life\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=13)\]

Metheny is the younger brother of jazz [flugelhornist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flugelhorn) [Mike Metheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Metheny). He lives in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City) with his wife, Latifa (née Azhar), and three children. Latifa has been credited for album photography.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-researchgate-324040116-26)[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-27)[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-guitarrecords-12312-28) Metheny was once in a relationship with [Sônia Braga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%B4nia_Braga).[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-globo-Metheny-Braga-29)

[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

American jazz guitarist and composer (born 1954)

| Pat Metheny |
| --- |
| [![Metheny in 2010](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Pat_metheny_orch2.jpg/440px-Pat_metheny_orch2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pat_metheny_orch2.jpg) Metheny in 2010 |
| Background information |
| Birth name | Patrick Bruce Metheny |
| Born | (1954-08-12) August 12, 1954 (age 69) [Lee's Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee%27s_Summit,_Missouri), Missouri, U.S. |
| Genres | - [Jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz) - [jazz fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz_fusion) - [Latin jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_jazz) - [progressive jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_jazz) |
| Occupation(s) | - Musician - composer - producer - professor |
| Instruments | Guitar |
| Years active | 1974–present |
| Labels | - [ECM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECM_Records) - [Geffen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geffen_Records) - [Warner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros.) - [Nonesuch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonesuch_Records) - Modern Recording |
| |
| Website | [patmetheny.com](http://patmetheny.com) |

Musical artist

**Patrick Bruce Metheny** ([/məˈθiːni/](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English) [_mə-THEE-nee_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key); born August 12, 1954) is an American [jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz) guitarist and composer.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-1)

He was the leader of the [Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group) (1977–2010) and continues to work in various small-combo, duet, and solo settings, as well as other side projects. His style incorporates elements of progressive and contemporary jazz, [latin jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_jazz), and [jazz fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz_fusion).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Yanow2010-2) He has three [gold albums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_albums) and 20 [Grammy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Awards),[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-methany2011-3)[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-4) and is the only person to have won Grammys in 10 categories.

## Biography\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=1)\]

### Early years and education\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=2)\]

Metheny was born in [Lee's Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee%27s_Summit,_Missouri), [Missouri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missouri). His father Dave played trumpet, his mother Lois sang, and his maternal grandfather Delmar was a professional trumpeter.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-6) Metheny's first instrument was the trumpet, on which he was taught by his brother, [Mike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Metheny). Pat's brother, father, and grandfather played trios together at home. His parents were fans of [Glenn Miller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glenn_Miller) and swing music. They took Pat to concerts to hear [Clark Terry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clark_Terry) and [Doc Severinsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doc_Severinsen), but they had little respect for guitar. Pat's interest in guitar increased around 1964 when he saw [the Beatles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beatles) perform on TV. For his 12th birthday, his parents allowed him to buy a guitar, which was a [Gibson ES-140](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibson_ES-140) 3/4.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

Pat Metheny's life changed after hearing the album _[Four & More](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_%26_More)_ by [Miles Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Davis). Soon after, he was captivated by [Wes Montgomery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wes_Montgomery)'s album _[Smokin' at the Half Note](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smokin%27_at_the_Half_Note)_ which was released in 1965. He cites the Beatles, [Miles Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Davis), and Montgomery as having the biggest impact on his music.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

When he was 15, Metheny won a scholarship from _[Down Beat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Down_Beat)_ magazine to a one-week jazz camp where he was mentored by guitarist [Attila Zoller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attila_Zoller), who then invited him to New York City to meet guitarist [Jim Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_(musician)) and bassist [Ron Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_Carter).[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Taylor1999-8)

While playing at a club in Kansas City, Metheny was approached by [Bill Lee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Franklin_Lee_III), a dean at the [University of Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Miami), and offered a scholarship. After less than a week at college, Metheny realized that playing guitar all day during his teens had left him unprepared for classes. He admitted this to Lee, who offered him a job to teach as a professor, as the school had recently introduced electric guitar as a course of study.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

He moved to Boston to teach at the [Berklee College of Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berklee_College_of_Music) with jazz vibraphonist [Gary Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Burton)[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Taylor1999-8) and established a reputation as a prodigy.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Chinen2010-9)

### Debut album\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=3)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Pat_Metheny_KJAZ.jpg/440px-Pat_Metheny_KJAZ.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pat_Metheny_KJAZ.jpg) Metheny at [KJAZ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KEXC) radio, [Alameda, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alameda,_California), December 1980

In 1974, he appeared on an album unofficially titled _[Jaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_(album))_ with pianist [Paul Bley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Bley), bassist [Jaco Pastorius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_Pastorius), and drummer [Bruce Ditmas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Ditmas) on Carol Goss's [Improvising Artists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Improvising_Artists) label—but he was unaware that he was being recorded.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-10) The next year he joined Gary Burton's band with guitarist [Mick Goodrick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Goodrick).

Metheny released his debut album, _[Bright Size Life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bright_Size_Life)_ ( [ECM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECM_Records), 1976), with [Jaco Pastorius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_Pastorius) on bass guitar and [Bob Moses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rakalam_Bob_Moses) on drums. His next album, _[Watercolors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watercolors_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (ECM, 1977), was the first time he recorded with pianist [Lyle Mays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyle_Mays), who became his most frequent collaborator. The album also featured [Danny Gottlieb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danny_Gottlieb), who became the drummer for the first version of the [Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group).[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Ginell-11) With Metheny, Mays, and Gottlieb, the fourth member was bassist [Mark Egan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Egan) when the album _[Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group_(album))_ (ECM, 1978) was released.

## Pat Metheny Group\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=4)\]

Main article: [Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Steve_Rodby_and_Pat_Metheny.jpg/440px-Steve_Rodby_and_Pat_Metheny.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Steve_Rodby_and_Pat_Metheny.jpg) Left to right: [Steve Rodby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Rodby) and Metheny

When _[Pat Metheny Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group_(album))_ (ECM, 1978) was released, the group was a quartet comprising, besides Metheny, [Danny Gottlieb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danny_Gottlieb) on drums, [Mark Egan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Egan) on bass, and [Lyle Mays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyle_Mays) on piano, [autoharp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autoharp), and synthesizer. All but Egan had played on Metheny's album _[Watercolors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watercolors_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (ECM, 1977), recorded a year before the first group album.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Niles-7)

The second group album, _[American Garage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Garage)_ (ECM, 1979), reached number 1 on the _Billboard_ jazz chart and crossed over onto the pop charts. From 1982 to 1985, the Pat Metheny Group released _[Offramp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Offramp_(album))_ (ECM, 1982), a live album, _[Travels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travels_(Pat_Metheny_Group_album))_ (ECM, 1983), _[First Circle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Circle_(album))_ (ECM, 1984), and _[The Falcon and the Snowman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Falcon_and_the_Snowman_(album))_ (EMI, 1985), a soundtrack album for the movie of the same name for which they collaborated on the single " [This Is Not America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/This_Is_Not_America)" with [David Bowie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Bowie). The song reached number 14 in the British Top 40 in 1985 and number 32 in the U.S.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-12)

_Offramp_ marked the first appearance of bassist [Steve Rodby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Rodby) (replacing Egan) and a Brazilian guest artist, [Nana Vasconcelos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nana_Vasconcelos), on percussion and wordless vocals. On _First Circle_, Argentinian singer and multi-instrumentalist [Pedro Aznar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Aznar) joined the group; as drummer, [Paul Wertico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Wertico) replaced Gottlieb. Both Rodby and Wertico were members of the [Simon and Bard Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Simon_(musician)) at the time and had played in Simon-Bard in [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago) before joining Metheny.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

_First Circle_ was Metheny's last album with ECM; he had been a key artist for the label but left following disagreements with the label's founder, [Manfred Eicher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manfred_Eicher).[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-13)

_[Still Life (Talking)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Still_Life_(Talking))_ ( [Geffen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geffen_Records), 1987) featured new group members trumpeter [Mark Ledford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Ledford), vocalist David Blamires, and percussionist [Armando Marçal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armando_Mar%C3%A7al). Aznar returned for vocals and guitar on _[Letter from Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter_from_Home_(album))_ (Geffen, 1989).

During this period the [Steppenwolf Theater Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steppenwolf_Theater_Company) of Chicago featured compositions by Metheny and Mays for their production of Lyle Kessler's play _[Orphans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orphans_(Lyle_Kessler_play))_, where it has remained special optional music for all productions of the play around the world since.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-14)

Metheny then again delved into solo and band projects, and four years went by before the release of the next group record, a live album titled _[The Road to You](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Road_to_You)_ (Geffen, 1993), which featured tracks from the two Geffen studio albums among new tunes. The group integrated new instrumentation and technologies into its work, notably Mays' use of synthesizers.

Metheny and Mays themselves refer to the next three Pat Metheny Group releases as a triptych:\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\] _[We Live Here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/We_Live_Here)_ (Geffen, 1995), _[Quartet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartet_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (Geffen, 1996), and _[Imaginary Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imaginary_Day)_ ( [Warner Bros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Records)., 1997). Moving away from the Latin style which had dominated the releases of the previous ten years, these albums included experiments with sequenced synthetic drums on one track, free-form improvisation on acoustic instruments, and symphonic signatures, blues, and sonata schemes.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

With _[Speaking of Now](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaking_of_Now)_ (Warner Bros., 2002), new group members were added: drummer [Antonio Sánchez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_S%C3%A1nchez_(drummer)) from [Mexico City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico_City), trumpeter [Cuong Vu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuong_Vu) from [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam), and bassist, vocalist, guitarist, and percussionist [Richard Bona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Bona) from [Cameroon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cameroon).

_[The Way Up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Way_Up)_ ( [Nonesuch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonesuch_Records), 2005) consists of a single 68-minute-long piece—split into four sections—based on a pair of three-note kernels: the opening B, A♯, F♯ and the derived B, A, F♯. On _The Way Up_, harmonica player [Grégoire Maret](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregoire_Maret) from Switzerland was introduced as a new group member, while Bona contributed as a guest musician.

## Side projects\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=5)\]

Outside the Group, Metheny has shown different sides of his musical personality. He made the album _[Orchestrion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orchestrion_(album))_ ( [Nonesuch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonesuch_Records), 2010) with elaborate, custom mechanical instruments which allowed him to compose and perform as a one-person orchestra. By contrast, his album _[Secret Story](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secret_Story_(album))_ (Geffen, 1992) used orchestral arrangements found more often in movie soundtracks, such as his own _[The Falcon and the Snowman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Falcon_and_the_Snowman_(album))_ (EMI, 1985) and _[A Map of the World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Map_of_the_World_(album))_ (Warner Bros., 1999). His solo acoustic guitar albums include _[New Chautauqua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Chautauqua)_ (ECM, 1979), _[One Quiet Night](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Quiet_Night)_ (Warner Bros., 2003), and _[What's It All About](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/What%27s_It_All_About_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (Nonesuch, 2011). He explored the fringes of the avant-garde on _[Zero Tolerance for Silence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_Tolerance_for_Silence)_ (Geffen, 1994). This, too, was an album of solo guitar, but it was electric guitar. Metheny had ventured into the avant-garde before on _[80/81](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/80/81)_ (ECM, 1980), _[Song X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_X)_ (Geffen, 1986) with [Ornette Coleman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ornette_Coleman), and _The Sign of Four_ with [Derek Bailey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_Bailey_(guitarist)) (Knitting Factory Works, 1997).

In 1997, Metheny recorded with bassist [Marc Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Johnson_(musician)) on Johnson's release _[The Sound of Summer Running](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sound_of_Summer_Running)_ (Verve, 1998). The next year, he recorded a [guitar duet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_%26_Pat_Metheny) with [Jim Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_(musician)) (Telarc, 1999), whose work has strongly influenced Metheny's. He collaborated with Polish jazz and folk singer [Anna Maria Jopek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Maria_Jopek) on _[Upojenie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upojenie)_ (Warner Poland, 2002) and [Bruce Hornsby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Hornsby) on _[Hot House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_House_(Bruce_Hornsby_album))_ (RCA, 2005).

He recorded on albums by his older brother, [Mike Metheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Metheny), a jazz trumpeter, among them _Day In – Night Out_ (1986) and _Close Enough for Love_ (2001).[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-15)[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-16)

The long list of his collaborators includes [Lyle Mays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyle_Mays), [Bill Frisell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Frisell), [Billy Higgins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Higgins), [Brad Mehldau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Mehldau), [Charlie Haden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Haden), [Chick Corea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chick_Corea), [Dave Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Holland), [Dewey Redman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dewey_Redman), [Eberhard Weber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eberhard_Weber), [Herbie Hancock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbie_Hancock), [Jack DeJohnette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_DeJohnette), [Jaco Pastorius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaco_Pastorius), [Jim Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_(musician)), [John Scofield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Scofield), [Joni Mitchell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joni_Mitchell), [David Bowie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Bowie), [Joshua Redman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_Redman), [Marc Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Johnson_(musician)), [Michael Brecker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Brecker), [Mick Goodrick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Goodrick), [Roy Haynes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Haynes), [Steve Swallow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Swallow), and [Tony Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Williams_(drummer)).[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Forte-17)

## Unity Band\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=6)\]

In 2012, he formed the Unity Band with [Antonio Sánchez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_S%C3%A1nchez_(drummer)) on drums, [Ben Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Williams_(musician)) on bass and [Chris Potter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Potter_(jazz_saxophonist)) on saxophone. This ensemble toured Europe and the U.S. during the latter half of the year. In 2013, as an extension of the Unity Band project, Metheny announced the formation of the Pat Metheny Unity Group, with the addition of the Italian multi-instrumentalist [Giulio Carmassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giulio_Carmassi).

## Influences\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=7)\]

As a young guitarist, Metheny tried to sound like [Wes Montgomery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wes_Montgomery), but when he was 14 or 15, he decided it was disrespectful to imitate him.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Ratliff2005-18) In the liner notes on the 2-disc Montgomery compilation _Impressions: The Verve Jazz Sides_, Metheny is quoted as saying, " _[Smokin' at the Half Note](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smokin%27_at_the_Half_Note)_ is the absolute greatest jazz-guitar album ever made. It is also the record that taught me how to play."

Ornette Coleman's 1968 album _[New York Is Now!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Is_Now!)_ inspired Metheny to find his own direction.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-Kitts2002-19) He has recorded Coleman's compositions on a number of albums, starting with a medley of "Round Trip" and "Broadway Blues" on his debut album, _Bright Size Life_ (1976). He worked extensively with Coleman's collaborators, such as [Charlie Haden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Haden), [Dewey Redman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dewey_Redman), and [Billy Higgins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Higgins), and he recorded the album _[Song X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_X)_ (1986) with Coleman and toured with him.

Metheny made three albums on ECM with Brazilian vocalist and percussionist [Naná Vasconcelos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nan%C3%A1_Vasconcelos). He lived in Brazil from the late 1980s to the early 1990s and performed with several local musicians, such as [Milton Nascimento](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milton_Nascimento) and [Toninho Horta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toninho_Horta). He played with [Antônio Carlos Jobim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B4nio_Carlos_Jobim) as a tribute, in a live performance in _[Carnegie Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall) Salutes The Jazz Masters: Verve 50th Anniversary_.

He is also a fan of several pop music artists, especially singer/songwriters including [James Taylor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Taylor) (after whom he named the song "James" on _Offramp_); [Bruce Hornsby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Hornsby), [Cheap Trick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheap_Trick), and [Joni Mitchell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joni_Mitchell), with whom he performed on her _[Shadows and Light](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shadows_and_Light_(Joni_Mitchell_album))_ ( [Asylum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asylum_Records)/ [Elektra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elektra_Records), 1980) live tour. Metheny is also fond of [Buckethead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckethead)'s music. He also worked with, sponsored or helped to make recordings of singer/songwriters from all over the world, such as [Pedro Aznar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Aznar) (Argentina), [Akiko Yano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akiko_Yano) (Japan), [David Bowie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Bowie) (UK), [Silje Nergaard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silje_Nergaard) (Norway), [Noa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achinoam_Nini) (Israel), and [Anna Maria Jopek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Maria_Jopek) (Poland).[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-20)

Two of Metheny's albums, _[The Way Up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Way_Up)_ (2005) and _[Orchestrion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orchestrion_(album))_ (2010), show the influence of American minimalist composer [Steve Reich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Reich) and use similar rhythmic figures structured around pulse. Metheny recorded Reich's composition _[Electric Counterpoint](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_Counterpoint)_ on Reich's album _[Different Trains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Different_Trains)_ (Nonesuch, 1987).

## Guitars\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=8)\]

### Pikasso\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=9)\]

Main article: [Pikasso guitar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pikasso_guitar)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/MethenyPikasso.JPG/440px-MethenyPikasso.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MethenyPikasso.JPG) Metheny with the 42-string Pikasso

Metheny plays a custom-made 42-string [Pikasso I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pikasso_guitar) created by Canadian luthier [Linda Manzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linda_Manzer). He plays it on "Into the Dream" and on the albums _[Quartet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartet_(Pat_Metheny_album))_ (1996), _[Imaginary Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imaginary_Day)_ (1997), _[Jim Hall & Pat Metheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Hall_%26_Pat_Metheny)_ (1999), _[Trio → Live](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trio_%E2%86%92_Live)_ (Warner Bros., 2000), and the _Speaking of Now Live_ and _Imaginary Day Live_ DVDs. Metheny has used the guitar in his guest appearances on other artists' albums. He used the Pikasso on _[Metheny/Mehldau Quartet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metheny/Mehldau_Quartet)_ (Nonesuch, 2007), his second collaboration with pianist [Brad Mehldau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Mehldau) and his trio sidemen [Larry Grenadier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Grenadier) and [Jeff Ballard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Ballard_(musician)); the Pikasso is featured on Metheny's composition "The Sound of Water". Manzer has made many acoustic guitars for Metheny, including a mini guitar, an acoustic sitar guitar, and the [baritone guitar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baritone_guitar), which Metheny used for the recording of _[One Quiet Night](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Quiet_Night)_ (2003).

### Guitar synthesizer\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=10)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Pat_Metheny_Venice.jpg/340px-Pat_Metheny_Venice.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pat_Metheny_Venice.jpg) Metheny with the guitar synthesizer

Metheny was one of the first jazz guitarists to use the [Roland GR-300](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roland_GR-300) [guitar synthesizer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guitar_synthesizer). He commented, "you have to stop thinking about it as a guitar, because it no longer is a guitar." He approaches it as if he were a horn player, and he prefers the "high trumpet" sound of the instrument.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-webb-21) One of the patches that he has often used is on Roland's JV-80 "Vintage Synth" expansion card, titled "Pat's GR-300".\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\] In addition to the Roland, he uses a [Synclavier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synclavier) controller.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-webb-21)

### Six-string and twelve-string electric\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=11)\]

Metheny was an early proponent of the [twelve-string guitar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelve-string_guitar) in jazz. During his 1975 tour with the [Gary Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Burton) "Quartet" (five people, including Metheny), he primarily played electric twelve-string guitar against the six-string work of resident guitarist [Mick Goodrick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Goodrick).[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-22)

Prior to Metheny, [Pat Martino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Martino) had used the electric twelve-string guitar on a studio album, _[Desperado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desperado_(Pat_Martino_album))_, and [John McLaughlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McLaughlin_(musician)) had used a double-neck electric guitar with the [Mahavishnu Orchestra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahavishnu_Orchestra). [Ralph Towner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Towner) was perhaps the first[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-23) to use acoustic twelve-string guitar extensively in jazz ("The Moors", from [Weather Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_Report)'s _[I Sing the Body Electric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Sing_the_Body_Electric_(album))_, Columbia, 1972), and [Larry Coryell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Coryell) and [Philip Catherine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Catherine) made extensive use of acoustic twelve string in alternate tunings at the 1975 [Montreux Jazz Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montreux_Jazz_Festival), later releasing some of the material on their 1976 _[Twin House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twin_House_(Larry_Coryell_%26_Philip_Catherine_album))_ album.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

Metheny used a twelve-string guitar on his debut album, _Bright Size Life_ (1976), including alternate tuning on "Sirabhorn", and on later albums ("San Lorenzo", from _Pat Metheny Group_ and _Travels_).\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

### Use of hollow-body electric guitars\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=12)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jazzvitoria_Metheny.jpg/440px-Jazzvitoria_Metheny.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jazzvitoria_Metheny.jpg) Metheny with his Ibanez PM signature model

At the age of 12, Metheny bought a natural finish [Gibson ES-175](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibson_ES-175) that he played throughout his early career, until it was retired in 1995.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-24) After his first tour of Japan in 1978, he began an association with [Ibanez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibanez) guitars, who have since produced a range of PM signature models.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-25)

## Personal life\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pat_Metheny&action=edit&section=13)\]

Metheny is the younger brother of jazz [flugelhornist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flugelhorn) [Mike Metheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Metheny). He lives in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City) with his wife, Latifa (née Azhar), and three children. Latifa has been credited for album photography.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-researchgate-324040116-26)[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-27)[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-guitarrecords-12312-28) Metheny was once in a relationship with [Sônia Braga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%B4nia_Braga).[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Metheny#cite_note-globo-Metheny-Braga-29)

results.content:
![](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/images/nXy69d2A.png)

[Home](https://www.allaboutjazz.com) »
[Jazz Musicians](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/musicians) »
Pat Metheny

Claim Page

# Pat Metheny

- [Biography](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/musicians/pat-metheny/#about)
- [Articles](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/musicians/pat-metheny/#articles)
- [News](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/musicians/pat-metheny/#news)
- [Influencers](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/musicians/pat-metheny/#influences)
- [Has Influenced](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/musicians/pat-metheny/#has_influenced)

[![Pat Metheny is an NEA Jazz Master](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/images/nea-jazz-masters.png)](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/updated-musician-pages?type=nea)

Pat Metheny was born in Kansas City on August 12, 1954 into a musical family. Starting on trumpet at the age of 8, Metheny switched to guitar at age 12. By the age of 15, he was working regularly with the best jazz musicians in Kansas City, receiving valuable on-the-bandstand experience at an unusually young age. Metheny first burst onto the international jazz scene in 1974. Over the course of his three-year stint with vibraphone great [Gary Burton](http://www.garyburton.com), the young Missouri native already displayed his soon-to-become trademarked playing style, which blended the loose and flexible articulation customarily reserved for horn players with an advanced rhythmic and harmonic sensibility - a way of playing and improvising that was modern in conception but grounded deeply in the jazz tradition of melody, swing, and the blues. With the release of his first album, [Bright Size Life (1975)](https://www.patmetheny.com/music/detail.cfm?id=17), he reinvented the traditional "jazz guitar" sound for a new generation of players. Throughout his career, Pat Metheny has continued to re-define the genre by utilizing new technology and constantly working to evolve the improvisational and sonic potential of his instrument. METHENY'S versatility is almost nearly without peer on any instrument. Over the years, he has performed with artists as diverse as [Steve Reich](http://www.stevereich.com/) to Ornette Coleman to [Herbie Hancock](http://www.herbiehancock.com/) to [Jim Hall](http://www.jimhallmusic.com/) to [Milton Nascimento](http://www.miltonnascimento.com.br/ingles.html) to [David Bowie](http://www.davidbowie.com/). Metheny's body of work includes compositions for solo guitar, small ensembles, electric and acoustic instruments, large orchestras, and ballet pieces, with settings ranging from modern jazz to rock to classical.

As well as being an accomplished musician, Metheny has also participated in the academic arena as a music educator. At 18, he was the youngest teacher ever at the University of Miami. At 19, he became the youngest teacher ever at the Berklee College of Music, where he also received an honorary doctorate more than twenty years later (1996). He has also taught music workshops all over the world, from the Dutch Royal Conservatory to the Thelonius Monk Institute of Jazz to clinics in Asia and South America. He has also been a true musical pioneer in the realm of electronic music, and was one of the very first jazz musicians to treat the synthesizer as a serious musical instrument. Years before the invention of MIDI technology, Metheny was using the Synclavier as a composing tool. He has also been instrumental in the development of several new kinds of guitars such as the soprano acoustic guitar, the 42-string Pikasso guitar, Ibanez's PM-100 jazz guitar, and a variety of other custom instruments. He took the whole instrument development process into a different level with his mechanical, solenoid driven Orchestrion.

[Read more](javascript:void(0);)

It is one thing to attain popularity as a musician, but it is another to receive the kind of acclaim Metheny has garnered from critics and peers. Over the years, Metheny has won countless polls as "Best Jazz Guitarist" and awards, including three gold records for [Still Life (Talking)](https://www.patmetheny.com/music/detail.cfm?id=42), [Letter from Home](https://www.patmetheny.com/music/detail.cfm?id=43), and [Secret Story](https://www.patmetheny.com/music/detail.cfm?id=27). He has also won 20 Grammy Awards in 12 different categories including Best Rock Instrumental, Best Contemporary Jazz Recording, Best Jazz Instrumental Solo, Best Instrumental Composition. The Pat Metheny Group won an unprecedented seven consecutive Grammies for seven consecutive albums. Metheny has spent most of his life on tour, averaging between 120-240 shows a year since 1974. At the time of this writing, he continues to be one of the brightest stars of the jazz community, dedicating time to both his own projects and those of emerging artists and established veterans alike, helping them to reach their audience as well as realizing their own artistic visions.

[Show less](https://www.allaboutjazz.com/musicians/pat-metheny/#bio-top)

by Chris May

July 27, 2024

Reissued as part of ECM's 180gm-vinyl audiophile Luminessence series, Bright Size Life was originally released in 1976 and features Pat Metheny leading his then regular touring trio completed by bassist Jaco Pastorius and drummer Bob Moses. It is a lively and lovely album and rediscovering it should be a delightful experience for anyone who has perhaps left it on the shelf for a few years, particularly delightful given the latest edition's sonic splendor.
